title: Use native OpenSSH client on newer Windows 10
author: Daniel15
body_snippet:
## Expected Behavior
Newer versions of Windows 10 include an SSH client. It would be great to use this, rather than using PuTTY. See https://www.howtogeek.com/336775/how-to-enable-and-use-windows-10s-built-in-ssh-commands/

## Current Behavior
mRemoteNG uses PuTTY

## Your Environment
* Version used: N/A
* Operating System and version: Windows 10 1809 x64

comments.author: sethbacon
comments.snippet:
Here is another solution for OpenSSH without putty:
1) Create a new external tool with the following 
  a) Display Name = openSSH
  b) Filename = c:\program files\powershell\7\pwsh.exe
  c) Arguments = -c "ssh -i ./.ssh/%PASSWORD% %USERNAME%@%HOSTNAME%"
  d) Working directory = $env:USERPROFILE
2) Drop your .pem file(s) in your .ssh folder under your user profile
3) Fill in Hostname, username for the connection
4) For password, enter the filename of your .pem file for this connection.

comments.author: themegabyte
comments.snippet:
Everyone, 

if you are using the **stable 2019** build of mRemoteNG, it is a 32-bit program, and hence will launch the 32-bit version of Powershell. That 32-bit verison of PS _won't have access to the openssh_ exe and hence will error out. 

Sharing to save your time.
Would be great to support this, also the SSH ProxyJump should definitely be available :)

the following worked for me (other solution was locking the mRemoteNG screen):

Arguments: `-NoLogo -NoProfile -Command  "& '%windir%\Sysnative\OpenSSH\ssh.exe' %USERNAME%@%HOSTNAME%"`
